author: daxian-dbw
body:
# PR Summary

We use the property names 'Light***' such as `LightRed` and `LightGreen` for VT sequences that [are documented](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/console-virtual-terminal-sequences#text-formatting) as "Bright Foreground \<color\>" and "Bright Background \<color\>", such as 'Bright Red' and 'Bright Green'. This is misleading, we should make the property names consistent with those in the documentation, so it's more intuitive for users to work with VT color in PowerShell.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/e98a8c8601b8f15f479e894323beafb9f6a2300c/src/System.Management.Automation/FormatAndOutput/common/PSStyle.cs#L78-L88

## More Context

The names were originally copied from the "command-line-api" repo [from `System.CommandLine.Rendering.Color+Foreground` and `System.CommandLine.Rendering.Color+Background`](https://github.com/dotnet/command-line-api/blob/cfefdc7a44f3682b626a8953976650ed91879e7e/src/System.CommandLine.Rendering/Ansi.cs#L29). Now it's been confirmed that those properties were misnamed in that repo and will be fixed there, see https://github.com/dotnet/command-line-api/issues/1438.

So we should fix in PowerShell as well, before 7.2 GA.

comments.author: JustinGrote
comments.body: Makes sense to me, since it is still preview and anyone working at this level is going to be used to these VT level color sequences, the consistency is appropriate.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: The `$PSStyle` is only in 7.2 previews, right? I don't see it in my 7.1.x install.  So is this really a breaking change? IMO you have the right to change anything in a preview.  That's why it's called "preview".  Once it hits RC or especially any sort of "go live" designation, then you shouldn't introduce a breaking change unless it meets a very high bar.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @rkeithhill it was added in 7.2, we made it stable in preview.10 (or 9?).  My opinion is to either change it now or never.  I'm leaving it to the WG to make a formal decision :)
